Yasou
Introduction

***
=

She was lovely=85 beautiful in her simplicity=85 soothing to his tortured =

spirit.

Koshima approached the young woman he had followed to the field o=
f 
June wildflowers, amused by how her lashes fluttered against her 
cheeks=
 as she cast her eyes downward in flirtatious propriety.  The 
corners of h=
er mouth tipped gently upward in a smile that on any 
other woman he would'=
ve taken for coyness.  Reds and golds sparkled 
in her brown hair as dapple=
d sunlight penetrated beyond the treetop 
canopy.

When he was close enough=
 to touch her, she lifted her face and looked 
directly into his eyes.  Her=
 voice was soft and inviting.  "My lord=85 "

"Shirou," he corrected her, g=
iving her the gift of his name as he 
crouched down before her.

She smiled=
 at the touch of his fingertips on her lips.  "Naname."

***

Had he been a=
ny other man, Saitou would've whistled.  As he was not 
any other man, Sait=
ou walked the wide street towards home in complete 
silence and bland decor=
um.  Commissioner Kawaji wasn't the only one 
who never knew what was going=
 on inside the Wolf's head.  Saitou 
intended to keep it that way.

His wor=
kday was officially over.  It wasn't as though government 
lackeys and unde=
rworld thugs weren't plotting away for their own 
selfish gain on any given=
 street in any town in Japan, but right now 
he couldn't be bothered too mu=
ch about it.  They'd still be there 
when he was ready to stop living the d=
ream life of an ordinary police 
inspector.

Two months strapped to a Tokyo=
 desk=85 he couldn't have been happier.

Not as happy, however, as about wh=
at he knew awaited him at the end 
of this journey.  Something new=85 somet=
hing fresh and alive and as 
vibrant as the flowers spilling over planters =
and hedge rows in the 
welcoming warmth of late spring.  Something that mad=
e Saitou feel 
reborn and young again.  Something unexpected in the form of=
 a young 
man by the name of Sagara Sanosuke.

The thought was more appetiz=
ing than anticipating his next bowl of 
plain, hot soba.

Saitou let a part=
 of his mind wander=85 a phenomenon rarely indulged.  
He could picture San=
osuke waiting for him, checking and rechecking 
the clock every five minute=
s as he listened for the familiar steps up 
the short walkway to the front =
of the house.  The impact of the 
strong body as he welcomed Saitou home --=
- his way of congratulating 
the cop for making it through to the end of an=
other day still alive --
- quickly becoming a routine neither would ever ti=
re of; a perfect 
touch to define the end of one part of the day and herald=
 the start 
of another.

It would wake Saitou up and rekindle the fire in d=
ulled senses, 
preparing him for the night to come.

As he stepped off the =
street and onto the walk, Saitou mentally 
braced himself to withstand the =
strength behind Sanosuke's exuberant 
greeting and unconsciously cursed the=
 politicians and yakuza who 
insisted on always untying the leash that kept=
 him behind a desk.
